Purpose
The purpose of this document is to set in place clear processes and procedures regarding the disposal of Trust assets that can be understood and followed by all Trust staff.
Introduction

It is important for the Trust to have in place a procedure for the disposal of assets. The procedure will provide staff members with detailed guidance and help to ensure that consistent work practices are followed.
The policy outlines a procedure that can be clearly audited. It also allows central records to be kept of all asset disposals.

This policy is designed to highlight the importance of the disposal procedure so as to maximise the potential proceeds for the Trust and avoid incurring any financial penalties within their respective budgets.

The policy also has the intention of reducing waste and subsequent emissions across the Trust and raise awareness of sustainable practices such as, re-use, recycle and appropriate disposal of equipment
Objectives
To ensure all inventories of assets are updated and maintained by departments, including the centrally held asset register which is maintained by the Finance function.
To identify equipment that is surplus to requirements.
To avoid retaining surplus equipment.
To maximise disposal proceeds for the Trust.
To discharge the Trust's duty to optimise the use of assets.
To make senior managers, directorate managers and budget holders aware of the financial impact on budgets surrounding disposals.
To minimise unnecessary equipment disposal to reduce the Trusts waste and subsequent emissions.
To maximise the re-use, repair and recycle of equipment, to reduce unnecessary spending and associated waste emissions.
Scope

This document includes disposals in relation to all Trust equipment with the exception of IT related assets which are managed solely by the IT Department. Any media retaining devices should be processed accordingly via the IT Department.

This document excludes the disposal of land and buildings. The disposal of land and buildings is co-ordinated by the Chief Commercial Officer, who acts as the informed agent to the Trust. Any disposal should maximise proceeds whilst still ensuring that it is in accordance with current NHS policy on the advertisement, auction and sale of any Land and Buildings. All disposals of land and buildings will require Business Case approval by the Trust Board. The Trust Board, using advice from the Estates Strategy Team, will decide on the method of disposal for Land and Buildings. This decision may be to demolish, sell or lease.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust

Chief Executive as Accounting Officer is responsible for the quality and safety of the services provided by the Trust. They have delegated the responsibility for the disposal of assets to the Director of Finance.
Chief Finance Officer

The Director of Finance must ensure that detailed procedures for the disposal of unprotected assets including condemnations are in place, and to ensure that all managers and staff are aware of their responsibilities regarding that process.
Executive Directors must ensure that the policy and procedure is implemented and that all managers are aware of their responsibilities in relation to this policy.

Health and Safety Risk Advisor is responsible for providing specialist advice on the current Health and Safety regulations and has the authority to implement immediate remedial action in an unsafe situation, where reasonably practical.

Fire Risk Advisor is responsible for providing specialist advice on the current fire regulations and has the authority to implement immediate remedial action in an unsafe situation, where reasonably practical.

Clinical Directors / Deputy Directors of Ops / Heads of Nursing and Midwifery The Directors /General Managers are responsible for the implementation and control measures put in place to reduce risks with regard to the disposal of equipment and that staff are aware of current health and safety legislation by attending health and safety training provided and encourage staff to observe and reduce risk.

Portering Manager is responsible for the collection of equipment in need of repair to be collected, or for disposal. It should be taken to the designated storage facilities and reported to the appropriate department.
Waste Managers
As part of the disposal process, MSE Waste Managers are also responsible to ensure that equipment is disposed of appropriately, please see Waste Policy.

Head of MEMS has responsibility for any broken medical equipment within the organisation. Any equipment that is unrepairable must be condemned. Condemned equipment must be decommissioned appropriately, and disposed of correctly, in accordance with health and safety legislation and MHRA guidance. They will be responsible for completing the appropriate documentation and remove the items from the MEMS equipment register.
Finance Department

It is the responsibility of the Finance Department to ensure that the asset register is updated and all parties have completed all relevant forms, internal and external audit will want to see evidence of appropriate disposal of equipment.
Equipment disposal policy statement

The identification of the disposal of equipment is the responsibility of the Departmental Lead assigned to the item of equipment. The departmental lead will need to complete Section 1 of the Equipment Disposal Form (Appendix 2) and then forward to the relevant condemning officer.
All items should be condemned or otherwise disposed of by an employee authorised by the Director of Finance.

All capital equipment assets that have a current net book value that are due to be sold, scrapped, exchanged or otherwise disposed of will need to be approved by the Chief Finance Officer. The finance department will be able to confirm if the asset has a current net book value.
All equipment disposals over with a Net Book Value of £250k will require business case approval by the Trust Board.

The relevant condemning officer will then be responsible for completing Section 2 of the Equipment Disposal Form (Appendix 2). The condemning officer will have the responsibility to assess the item and decide whether to either, dispose, sell or relocate it, seeking advice and support where necessary. Where appropriate efforts should be taken to see if equipment can be re-used or recycled.

In making their decision, the relevant department would need to take into consideration any contractual obligations attached to the item, as there may be clauses that prescribe/prohibit certain methods of disposal.
Any maintenance agreement associated with a disposal will require cancelling or transferring and should be dealt with in accordance with the contract by the appropriate officer.

If it is decided that there is no use for the item within the Trust and no value in selling the item, then the item should be scrapped. The process involved for items identified for scrapping can be found in the Trusts Waste Policy.

Where an item is to be relocated within the Trust, including relocating to the medical equipment library, then this should be arranged between the respective departments. It is the responsibility of the departmental lead from which the equipment is being removed to ensure that the appropriate departments are notified to ensure the records can be updated. (e.g. finance register, Medusa database)
Any item that stores patient identifiable data on it must have the data removed prior to disposal of any form. A certificate of destruction is required where appropriate.
Equipment disposal procedure

It is the responsibility of the Ward Manager, or the deputy in their absence to ensure the equipment, when broken, is clearly labelled, using the appropriate notice, reported to MEMS, if medical equipment, and taken out of use. If involved in an incident, ensure that an incident form has been completed with the Trusts unique equipment inventory number on it.

Any equipment which is unsafe must be withdrawn from use immediately. It should be removed from the working environment or clearly labelled to prevent others from using it. All members of staff are responsible for withdrawing, labelling and reporting items of equipment which they find to be defective.
MEMS will determine if the medical equipment is repairable, if so, arrange for the repair. If unable to repair, complete the relevant form for condemning, recording all the necessary details.

It is the responsibility of MEMS to seek the approval from the Finance Department before the medical equipment is disposed of. This is completed via the MEMS decommissioning process, items will be marked as “Inactive pending finance decommissioning” on Medusa, finance will receive a list of these items via a routine report. Items with NIL NBV will be reported back to MEMS with authorisation for disposal. Items with NBV will be processed separately.

If an item is identified as being surplus to the Trust's requirements it should be disposed of in the most economical and environmental manner – maximising proceeds to the Trust whilst complying with the relevant legislation and guidance, maximising proceeds to the Trust whilst also actively reducing waste and associated waste emissions across MSE.
The disposal value may be nil, but nevertheless the same process must be followed.
Competitive Tendering or Quotation procedures shall not apply to the disposal of (as per MEHT SFI7.13.1):
Any matter in respect of which a fair price can be obtained only negotiation or sale by auction as determined (or pre-determined in a reserve) by the Chief Executive or his nominated officer;
For such items, where it is appropriate to invite tenders, these should be invited in accordance with the tendering procedure set out in the Trust's SFI's.
Where auction is the appropriate method of disposal a reputable auction house should be used which complies with the relevant legislation and guidance as described in 5.2.

Care must be taken at the time of disposal to identify any restrictions on the use of sale proceeds: if the asset being sold was originally purchased through charitable funds, the proceeds (if any) must be handled in accordance with the particular charitable fund terms – usually returned to the fund for reinvestment.

The sales invoice is to specify “sold as seen” with a full disclaimer issued for liability for any injury, damage or loss which may arise from the use of the asset disposed from the date of sale, the purchaser being responsible for costs of removal, and in the case of electrical equipment for safety testing by a qualified electrician. If applicable the invoice should state an asset register reference to enable the designated Finance Manager to adjust the register and make the correct accounting entries to reflect the disposal.

Disposal can be in various forms including but not limited to resale through auction house, sale to private, repurpose/donation into wider NHS system and dismantle/disposal through WEEE streams. The decision to sell, rather than dispose, medical equipment must take into consideration a risk assessment as to the condition of the equipment.
Before transfer of ownership the Trust and the purchaser must both be clear about their legal liabilities. Separate legal guidance should be sought if required.
All relevant paperwork should accompany the item on disposal. i.e. all instruction manuals; service records; and additional guidance supplied by the manufacturers, regulatory bodies etc.
If any of the aforementioned is not available, or the item has not been serviced as recommended a statement detailing this should accompany the item.

Exceptionally, disposals of capital assets or items of inventory may be made by invitation to staff to submit sealed bids (e.g. for redundant office furniture). A member of the Executive Team should prior approve this method of disposal.

Care must be taken to publicise the process equally and fairly across all the staff of the organisation, invite and observe sealed bids, notify and observe any minimum “reserve” and ensure the payment and removal are clearly stated as the responsibility of the successful bidder.

Staff will be required to sign a form accepting full responsibility for items purchased from the organisation, and goods will not carry any warranty. However, the organisation may in law retain some responsibility for the safe use and ultimate disposal of goods or equipment supplied to staff where such goods are not readily available to the general public; this method of disposal must be avoided in such cases.
Finance

Where capital assets are sold, scrapped, lost or otherwise disposed of, their value must be removed from the accounting records and each disposal must be validated by reference to authorisation documents and invoices where appropriate. Asset disposals for value shall be accounted through the Sales ledger, with the account being raised by the manager responsible for the disposal and coded to capital receipts (for assets in the asset register) or appropriate revenue income code (for inventory or other assets). In addition to this, the Finance Capital team are to be informed and the equipment is disposed of from the Trust's asset register

The sales invoice is to specify “sold as seen” with a full disclaimer issued for liability for any injury, damage or loss which may arise from the use of the asset disposed from the date of sale, the purchaser being responsible for costs of removal, and in the case of electrical equipment for safety testing by a qualified electrician. The invoice should state an asset register reference to enable the designated finance manager to adjust the register and make the correct accounting entries to reflect the disposal.

If the disposal of an asset gives rise to a taxable transaction, the organisation must account for VAT at current rates at the tax point of the disposal: if there is identifiable input tax related to a VAT-able disposal, this may be reclaimed.

Finance will update the asset register on a regular basis from information received from the departments when capital assets are disposed. Those with a net book value will have financial consequences to the department's budget.
The finance department are responsible for ensuring a rolling asset verification exercise is undertaken.
Breaches of policy
Any breach to the policy will be identified, recorded on Datix and will be formally investigated.
Training requirements
There are no specific training requirements.
Monitoring and audit

Regular reviews will be carried out to check that all disposals from the equipment asset register have adhered to this policy and all requisite forms have been completed. This process will also be subject to internal/external audit scrutiny.
Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Investment Group which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policies and guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Investment Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Preliminary equality analysis
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
